text: AM-GM Inequality: For positive reals ω1, . . . , ωn and a1, . . . , an the following holds true: ∑n i=1 ωiai∑n i=1 ωi ≥ Pn i=1 ωi v u u √ n∏ i=1 a ωi i Yay that was pretty scary looking. Here’s a slightly less intimidating form (though sometimes you will want to use the above form): a1 + a2 + . . . an n ≥ n√a1a2 . . . an Surprisingly, this is all you will need to know for this lecture other than basic algebra and the fact that x2 ≥ 0. The rest will be problems, because inequalities are a diﬃcult concept to master and the best way to master anything is to do a lot of problems! 1. Verify that a2 + b2 ≥ 2ab, ﬁrst with AM-GM and then with the fact that x2 ≥ 0. 2. If abc = 1, minimize a3 + b3 + c3 for positive reals a,b,c. 3. For x ≥ 0, minimize x2 + 2 x . 4. For a, b ≥ 0, maximize 2ab a2+b2 . 5. For a, b ≥ 0, maximize 6ab a2+9b2 . 6. For x ≥ 0, minimize x + 1 x+1 (no Calculus!). 7. For x ≥ 0, minimize x3+2 x+3 . 8. Which is bigger, 2007! or (1003)2007? 9. If you can have 1 of one coin, 5 of another coin, and 10 of a third coin, and can choose pennies, nickels, and dimes, in what way should you choose the coins to maximize your net gain? 10.
